value_proposition.problem: Developers waste resources using heavyweight verification for low-stakes interactions, or expose risk using lightweight verification for high-stakes ones
value_proposition.fix: Match verification cost to interaction stakes using clear decision criteria
value_proposition.benefit: Right-sized security - optimal cost/latency for each scenario

default_tier_assignment.name: Project-Type Defaults
default_tier_assignment.description: Assign default trust tiers based on project characteristics (single agent, multi-agent, cross-org, financial, critical)
default_tier_assignment.usage: Use L0 for single/multi-agent internal, L1 for cross-org, L2+ for financial/critical infrastructure
default_tier_assignment.use_when: Use L0 for single/multi-agent internal, L1 for cross-org, L2+ for financial/critical infrastructure
default_tier_assignment.code_example:
# Implement default_tier_assignment per trust-tier-decision-matrix patterns
# See description and related documentation
best_practices: Document the pattern usage and rationale in code comments
Validate implementation against domain requirements before deployment
Start with L0 (local verification) for all internal agent interactions - escalate only when requirements demand it
Use economic value as primary decision factor - <$100 starts at L0, $100-$10K considers L1, $10K+ considers L2+
Always escalate by one tier when interactions cross organizational boundaries (cross-society = true)
Require minimum L1 (attested) when audit trails are needed for compliance or regulatory purposes
Use L2 (contracted) or higher when automated enforcement or dispute resolution is required
Monitor violation patterns and automatically escalate tier when thresholds are exceeded (3+ violations in 24 hours)
Document tier selection rationale in decision records - capture why specific tier was chosen for future reference
Allow de-escalation after 7 days of good behavior to restore efficiency while maintaining security

anti_patterns.name: Over-Engineering Low-Stakes Interactions
anti_patterns.problem: Using L2/L3 verification for simple internal agent status updates wastes resources and adds unnecessary latency
anti_patterns.fix: Start with L0 for all internal interactions, escalate only when economic value, audit requirements, or cross-boundary needs justify it

anti_patterns.name: Ignoring Cross-Boundary Risks
anti_patterns.problem: Using L0 verification for interactions between different organizations exposes risk without audit trail
anti_patterns.fix: Always increase tier by at least one level when cross_society is true, use minimum L1 for cross-organizational interactions

anti_patterns.name: Static Tier Assignment
anti_patterns.problem: Setting trust tier once and never adjusting leads to either over-secured (wasteful) or under-secured (risky) interactions
anti_patterns.fix: Implement dynamic escalation/de-escalation based on violation patterns, dispute resolution times, and compliance periods

anti_patterns.name: Ignoring Economic Value
anti_patterns.problem: Using same tier for $10 transactions and $100K transactions wastes resources on low-value or exposes risk on high-value
anti_patterns.fix: Always assess economic value at risk first, use value thresholds (<$100, $100-$10K, $10K-$100K, $100K+) to guide initial tier selection

anti_patterns.name: Missing Audit Requirements
anti_patterns.problem: Using L0 verification when compliance requires audit trails leads to regulatory violations and inability to prove compliance
anti_patterns.fix: Always check audit requirements first - if audit trail is needed, use minimum L1 (attested) regardless of economic value
